awd_titl_txt: Biocompatible Flexible Microfabricated Sensors for Surgical Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology to address hearing loss and exploring follow-on applications of the technology. This project aims to improve outcomes and safety of Cochlear Implant surgery and help relieve the burden and costs (estimated $981B) of hearing loss to patients globally. In the US alone, lost productivity due to hearing loss costs up to $194B annually. There is also a large personal cost as people with hearing loss reported higher cases of loneliness, depression, and isolation. This technology will provide real-time feedback to surgeons to refine their surgical technique, as well as provide an unprecedented clinical dataset to surgeons and care providers to guide post-op care. Together, these will allow patients who undergo Cochlear Implant surgery to improve preservation of their residual hearing and reduce the risk of poor surgical outcomes. By addressing barriers to adoption, this technology can re-connect more people with the hearing world.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a sensor technology and intraoperative guidance system to improve hearing outcomes after Cochlear Implant surgery. Hearing loss is a leading cause of disability worldwide, responsible for an estimated $981B in global costs. This project aims to develop and deploy Micro Electro-Mechanical System sensors integrated with Cochlear Implants to quantitatively monitor the electrode position and forces in real-time in order to augment the surgeon’s tactile feedback. The sensor technology coupled with a Machine Learning guidance system will allow technique refinement within and across patients. Cochlear Implant surgery will yield more consistent hearing outcomes, including residual hearing preservation. Moreover, the data generated by this sensor system will enable new intra- and post-operative protocols as the medical community better understands the pitfalls during implantation. Improved surgical outcomes and rehabilitation plans enabled by this approach will facilitate broader regulatory approval for expanded eligibility and boost patient adoption. This technology will expand the market for Cochlear Implants, can improve hearing and quality of life by helping reduce isolation, depression, and loneliness associated with hearing loss.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF I-Corps grant sought to research commercial applications for a novel flexible, biocompatible strain-sensing technology developed at Carnegie Mellon University. The goals of this technology is to improve outcomes for patients undergoing cochlear implant (CI) surgery. By integrating ultra-thin (<10 micrometers) Micro Electro-Mechanical System (MEMS) sensors directly into the CI electrode, this technology enables a real-time guidance system to measure real-time insertion force and electrode positioning—two critical metrics shown to affect CI performance. Current CI insertion methods often rely on a surgeon’s tactile feel, leading to outcome variability. This technology addresses this gap by providing surgeons with quantitative feedback, allowing them to adjust their technique and reduce the risk of surgical trauma. 

The team was composed of Entrepreneurial Lead (EL) Hannah Mormer, who led the customer discovery process and business model development, supported by Industry Mentor Elora Gupta and Technical Lead Jay Reddy. Principal Investigator Maysam Chamanzar oversaw the customer discovery process and formation of a commercialization strategy.

During the I-Corps program, the team performed extensive customer discovery, interviewing clinicians, industry partners, and healthcare providers to validate our understanding of the problem and refine the potential solution. These interviews confirmed that real-time data would significantly improve surgical confidence and outcomes, and potentially streamline clinical workflows. Feedback from CI manufacturers steered the team to developing an integrated sensor solution that is compatible with existing implant designs. In addition, conversations with medical professionals in other surgical areas suggested broader surgical applications for the flexible sensor technology.

The team was able to refine the technology value proposition. By developing an integrated solution, the technology can be deployed without the need for additional hospital billing codes or time-consuming equipment setup. The team developed and tested a business model to partner for commercialization with existing implant manufacturers, to enable faster adoption and leverage their existing distribution networks. Further, the patient benefit and societal impact was explored: enhanced CI performance can lead to broader adoption and enhance patient quality of life. 

Overall, the NSF I-Corps support allowed the team to refine its commercialization strategy and lay the groundwork for future efforts to perform manufacturing scale-up, pursue regulatory clearance, and commercialize the technology alongside medical device manufacturers.


 

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2025
Modified by: Maysamreza Chamanzar
